统计场论第五章

Perturbative renormalization group

5.1 Expectation values in the Gaussian model

Can we treat the Landau-Ginzburg Hamiltonian as a perturbation to the Gaussian model? In particular, for zero magnetic field, we shall examine

βH=βH0+U≡∫ ddx[t2m2+K2(∇m)2+L2(∇2m)2+⋯ ]+u∫ ddxm4+⋯\begin{align*} \beta \mathcal{H}= & \beta \mathcal{H}_{0}+U \equiv \int \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{x}\left[\frac{t}{2} m^{2}+\frac{K}{2}(\nabla m)^{2}+\frac{L}{2}\left(\nabla^{2} m\right)^{2}+\cdots\right] \tag{5.1}\\ & +u \int \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{x} m^{4}+\cdots \end{align*}βH=​βH0​+U≡∫ ddx[2t​m2+2K​(∇m)2+2L​(∇2m)2+⋯]+u∫ ddxm4+⋯​(5.1)​

The unperturbed Gaussian Hamiltonian can be decomposed into independent Fourier modes, as

βH0=1V∑qt+Kq2+Lq4+⋯2∣m(q)∣2≡∫ ddq(2π)dt+Kq2+Lq4+⋯2∣m(q)∣2\begin{align*} \beta \mathcal{H}_{0} & =\frac{1}{V} \sum_{\mathbf{q}} \frac{t+K q^{2}+L q^{4}+\cdots}{2}|m(\mathbf{q})|^{2} \tag{5.2}\\ & \equiv \int \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{d}} \frac{t+K q^{2}+L q^{4}+\cdots}{2}|m(\mathbf{q})|^{2} \end{align*}βH0​​=V1​q∑​2t+Kq2+Lq4+⋯​∣m(q)∣2≡∫(2π)d ddq​2t+Kq2+Lq4+⋯​∣m(q)∣2​(5.2)​

The perturbative interaction which mixes up the normal modes has the form

U=u∫ ddxm(x)4+⋯=u∫ ddx∫ ddq1 ddq2 ddq3 ddq4(2π)4de−ix⋅(q1+q2+q3+q4)mα(q1)mα(q2)mβ(q3)mβ(q4)+⋯ ,\begin{align*} \mathcal{U}= & u \int \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{x} m(\mathbf{x})^{4}+\cdots \\ = & u \int \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{x} \int \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q}_{1} \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q}_{2} \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q}_{3} \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q}_{4}}{(2 \pi)^{4 d}} \mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{i} \mathbf{x} \cdot\left(\mathbf{q}_{1}+\mathbf{q}_{2}+\mathbf{q}_{3}+\mathbf{q}_{4}\right)} m_{\alpha}\left(\mathbf{q}_{1}\right) m_{\alpha}\left(\mathbf{q}_{2}\right) m_{\beta}\left(\mathbf{q}_{3}\right) m_{\beta}\left(\mathbf{q}_{4}\right) \\ & +\cdots, \tag{5.3} \end{align*}U==​u∫ ddxm(x)4+⋯u∫ ddx∫(2π)4d ddq1​ ddq2​ ddq3​ ddq4​​e−ix⋅(q1​+q2​+q3​+q4​)mα​(q1​)mα​(q2​)mβ​(q3​)mβ​(q4​)+⋯,​(5.3)​

where summation over α\alphaα and β\betaβ is implicit. The integral over x\mathbf{x}x sets q1+q2+\mathbf{q}_{1}+\mathbf{q}_{2}+q1​+q2​+ q3+q4=0\mathbf{q}_{3}+\mathbf{q}_{4}=\mathbf{0}q3​+q4​=0, and

u=u∫ ddq1 ddq2 ddq3(2π)3dmα(q1)mα(q2)mβ(q3)mβ(−q1−q2−q3)+⋯ .\begin{equation*} \mathcal{u}=u \int \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q}_{1} \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q}_{2} \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q}_{3}}{(2 \pi)^{3 d}} m_{\alpha}\left(\mathbf{q}_{1}\right) m_{\alpha}\left(\mathbf{q}_{2}\right) m_{\beta}\left(\mathbf{q}_{3}\right) m_{\beta}\left(-\mathbf{q}_{1}-\mathbf{q}_{2}-\mathbf{q}_{3}\right)+\cdots . \tag{5.4} \end{equation*}u=u∫(2π)3d ddq1​ ddq2​ ddq3​​mα​(q1​)mα​(q2​)mβ​(q3​)mβ​(−q1​−q2​−q3​)+⋯.​(5.4)​

From the variance of the Gaussian weights, the two-point expectation values in a finite sized system with discretized modes are easily obtained as

⟨mα(q)mβ(q′)⟩0=δq,−q′δα,βVt+Kq2+Lq4+⋯.\begin{equation*} \left\langle m_{\alpha}(\mathbf{q}) m_{\beta}\left(\mathbf{q}^{\prime}\right)\right\rangle_{0}=\frac{\delta_{\mathbf{q},-\mathbf{q}^{\prime}} \delta_{\alpha, \beta} V}{t+K q^{2}+L q^{4}+\cdots} . \tag{5.5} \end{equation*}⟨mα​(q)mβ​(q′)⟩0​=t+Kq2+Lq4+⋯δq,−q′​δα,β​V​.​(5.5)​

In the limit of infinite size, the spectrum becomes continuous, and Eq. (5.5) goes over to

⟨mα(q)mβ(q′)⟩0=δα,β(2π)dδd(q+q′)t+Kq2+Lq4+⋯\begin{equation*} \left\langle m_{\alpha}(\mathbf{q}) m_{\beta}\left(\mathbf{q}^{\prime}\right)\right\rangle_{0}=\frac{\delta_{\alpha, \beta}(2 \pi)^{d} \delta^{d}\left(\mathbf{q}+\mathbf{q}^{\prime}\right)}{t+K q^{2}+L q^{4}+\cdots} \tag{5.6} \end{equation*}⟨mα​(q)mβ​(q′)⟩0​=t+Kq2+Lq4+⋯δα,β​(2π)dδd(q+q′)​​(5.6)​

The subscript 0 is used to indicate that the expectation values are taken with respect to the unperturbed (Gaussian) Hamiltonian. Expectation values involving any product of mmm 's can be obtained starting from the identity

⟨exp⁡[∑iaimi]⟩0=exp⁡[∑i,jaiaj2⟨mimj⟩0],\begin{equation*} \left\langle\exp \left[\sum_{i} a_{i} m_{i}\right]\right\rangle_{0}=\exp \left[\sum_{i, j} \frac{a_{i} a_{j}}{2}\left\langle m_{i} m_{j}\right\rangle_{0}\right], \tag{5.7} \end{equation*}⟨exp[i∑​ai​mi​]⟩0​=exp[i,j∑​2ai​aj​​⟨mi​mj​⟩0​],​(5.7)​

which is valid for any set of Gaussian distributed variables {mi}\left\{m_{i}\right\}{mi​}. (This is easily seen by "completing the square.") Expanding both sides of the equation in powers of {ai}\left\{a_{i}\right\}{ai​} leads to

1+ai⟨mi⟩0+aiaj2⟨mimj⟩0+aiajak6⟨mimjmk⟩0+aiajakal24⟨mimjmkmk⟩0+⋯=1+aiaj2⟨mimj⟩0+aiajakal24(⟨mimj⟩0⟨mkml⟩0+⟨mimk⟩0⟨mjml⟩0+⟨mimk⟩0⟨mjml⟩0)+⋯\begin{align*} 1 & +a_{i}\left\langle m_{i}\right\rangle_{0}+\frac{a_{i} a_{j}}{2}\left\langle m_{i} m_{j}\right\rangle_{0}+\frac{a_{i} a_{j} a_{k}}{6}\left\langle m_{i} m_{j} m_{k}\right\rangle_{0}+\frac{a_{i} a_{j} a_{k} a_{l}}{24}\left\langle m_{i} m_{j} m_{k} m_{k}\right\rangle_{0}+\cdots= \\ 1 & +\frac{a_{i} a_{j}}{2}\left\langle m_{i} m_{j}\right\rangle_{0}+\frac{a_{i} a_{j} a_{k} a_{l}}{24}\left(\left\langle m_{i} m_{j}\right\rangle_{0}\left\langle m_{k} m_{l}\right\rangle_{0}+\left\langle m_{i} m_{k}\right\rangle_{0}\left\langle m_{j} m_{l}\right\rangle_{0}\right. \\ & \left.+\left\langle m_{i} m_{k}\right\rangle_{0}\left\langle m_{j} m_{l}\right\rangle_{0}\right)+\cdots \tag{5.8} \end{align*}11​+ai​⟨mi​⟩0​+2ai​aj​​⟨mi​mj​⟩0​+6ai​aj​ak​​⟨mi​mj​mk​⟩0​+24ai​aj​ak​al​​⟨mi​mj​mk​mk​⟩0​+⋯=+2ai​aj​​⟨mi​mj​⟩0​+24ai​aj​ak​al​​(⟨mi​mj​⟩0​⟨mk​ml​⟩0​+⟨mi​mk​⟩0​⟨mj​ml​⟩0​+⟨mi​mk​⟩0​⟨mj​ml​⟩0​)+⋯​(5.8)​

Matching powers of {ai}\left\{a_{i}\right\}{ai​} on the two sides of the above equation gives

⟨∏i=1ℓmi⟩0={0 for ℓ odd  sum over all pairwise contractions  for ℓ even. (5.9)\left\langle\prod_{i=1}^{\ell} m_{i}\right\rangle_{0}= \begin{cases}0 & \text { for } \ell \text { odd } \tag{5.9}\\ \text { sum over all pairwise contractions } & \text { for } \ell \text { even. }\end{cases}⟨i=1∏ℓ​mi​⟩0​={0 sum over all pairwise contractions ​ for ℓ odd  for ℓ even. ​(5.9)

This result is known as Wick's theorem; and for example,

⟨mimjmkml⟩0=⟨mimj⟩0⟨mkml⟩0+⟨mimk⟩0⟨mjml⟩0+⟨mimk⟩0⟨mjml⟩0\left\langle m_{i} m_{j} m_{k} m_{l}\right\rangle_{0}=\left\langle m_{i} m_{j}\right\rangle_{0}\left\langle m_{k} m_{l}\right\rangle_{0}+\left\langle m_{i} m_{k}\right\rangle_{0}\left\langle m_{j} m_{l}\right\rangle_{0}+\left\langle m_{i} m_{k}\right\rangle_{0}\left\langle m_{j} m_{l}\right\rangle_{0}⟨mi​mj​mk​ml​⟩0​=⟨mi​mj​⟩0​⟨mk​ml​⟩0​+⟨mi​mk​⟩0​⟨mj​ml​⟩0​+⟨mi​mk​⟩0​⟨mj​ml​⟩0​

5.2 Expectation values in perturbation theory

In the presence of an interaction U\mathcal{U}U, the expectation value of any operator O\mathcal{O}O is computed perturbatively as

⟨O⟩=∫Dm⃗Oe−βH0−U∫Dm⃗e−βH0−U=∫Dm⃗e−βH0O[1−U+U2/2−⋯ ]∫Dm⃗e−βH0[1−U+U2/2−⋯ ]=Z0[⟨O⟩0−⟨OU⟩0+⟨OU2⟩0/2−⋯ ]Z0[1−⟨U⟩0+⟨U2⟩0/2−⋯ ].\begin{align*} \langle\mathcal{O}\rangle & =\frac{\int \mathcal{D} \vec{m} \mathcal{O} \mathrm{e}^{-\beta \mathcal{H}_{0}-\mathcal{U}}}{\int \mathcal{D} \vec{m} \mathrm{e}^{-\beta} \mathcal{H}_{0}-\mathcal{U}}=\frac{\int \mathcal{D} \vec{m} \mathrm{e}^{-\beta \mathcal{H}_{0}} \mathcal{O}\left[1-\mathcal{U}+\mathcal{U}^{2} / 2-\cdots\right]}{\int \mathcal{D} \vec{m} \mathrm{e}^{-\beta} \mathcal{H}_{0}\left[1-\mathcal{U}+\mathcal{U}^{2} / 2-\cdots\right]} \tag{5.10}\\ & =\frac{Z_{0}\left[\langle\mathcal{O}\rangle_{0}-\langle\mathcal{O U}\rangle_{0}+\left\langle\mathcal{O} \mathcal{U}^{2}\right\rangle_{0} / 2-\cdots\right]}{Z_{0}\left[1-\langle\mathcal{U}\rangle_{0}+\left\langle\mathcal{U}^{2}\right\rangle_{0} / 2-\cdots\right]} . \end{align*}⟨O⟩​=∫Dme−βH0​−U∫DmOe−βH0​−U​=∫Dme−βH0​[1−U+U2/2−⋯]∫Dme−βH0​O[1−U+U2/2−⋯]​=Z0​[1−⟨U⟩0​+⟨U2⟩0​/2−⋯]Z0​[⟨O⟩0​−⟨OU⟩0​+⟨OU2⟩0​/2−⋯]​.​(5.10)​

Inverting the denominator by an expansion in powers of U\mathcal{U}U gives

⟨O⟩=[⟨O⟩0−⟨OU⟩0+12⟨OU2⟩0−⋯ ][1+⟨U⟩0+⟨U⟩02−12⟨U2⟩0−⋯ ]=⟨O⟩0−(⟨OU⟩0−⟨O⟩0⟨U⟩0)+12(⟨OU2⟩0−2⟨OU⟩0⟨U⟩0+2⟨O⟩0⟨U⟩02−⟨O⟩0⟨U2⟩0)+⋯≡∑n=0∞(−1)nn!⟨OUn⟩0c\begin{align*} \langle\mathcal{O}\rangle= & {\left[\langle\mathcal{O}\rangle_{0}-\langle\mathcal{O U}\rangle_{0}+\frac{1}{2}\left\langle\mathcal{O} \mathcal{U}^{2}\right\rangle_{0}-\cdots\right]\left[1+\langle\mathcal{U}\rangle_{0}+\langle\mathcal{U}\rangle_{0}^{2}-\frac{1}{2}\left\langle\mathcal{U}^{2}\right\rangle_{0}-\cdots\right] } \\ = & \langle\mathcal{O}\rangle_{0}-\left(\langle\mathcal{O U}\rangle_{0}-\langle\mathcal{O}\rangle_{0}\langle\mathcal{U}\rangle_{0}\right)+\frac{1}{2}\left(\left\langle\mathcal{O} \mathcal{U}^{2}\right\rangle_{0}-2\langle\mathcal{O U}\rangle_{0}\langle\mathcal{U}\rangle_{0}\right. \\ & \left.+2\langle\mathcal{O}\rangle_{0}\langle\mathcal{U}\rangle_{0}^{2}-\langle\mathcal{O}\rangle_{0}\left\langle\mathcal{U}^{2}\right\rangle_{0}\right)+\cdots \\ \equiv & \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{(-1)^{n}}{n!}\left\langle\mathcal{O} \mathcal{U}^{n}\right\rangle_{0}^{c} \tag{5.11} \end{align*}⟨O⟩==≡​[⟨O⟩0​−⟨OU⟩0​+21​⟨OU2⟩0​−⋯][1+⟨U⟩0​+⟨U⟩02​−21​⟨U2⟩0​−⋯]⟨O⟩0​−(⟨OU⟩0​−⟨O⟩0​⟨U⟩0​)+21​(⟨OU2⟩0​−2⟨OU⟩0​⟨U⟩0​+2⟨O⟩0​⟨U⟩02​−⟨O⟩0​⟨U2⟩0​)+⋯n=0∑∞​n!(−1)n​⟨OUn⟩0c​​(5.11)​

The connected averages (cumulants) are defined as the combination of unperturbed expectation values appearing at various orders in the expansion. Their significance will become apparent in diagrammatic representations, and from the following example.

Let us calculate the two-point correlation function of the Landau-Ginzburg model to first order in the parameter uuu. (In view of their expected irrelevance, we shall ignore higher order interactions, and also only keep the lowest order Gaussian terms.) Substituting Eq. (5.4) into Eq. (5.11) yields

⟨mα(q)mβ(q′)⟩=⟨mα(q)mβ(q′)⟩0−u∫ ddq1 ddqddq3(2π)3d×[⟨mα(q)mβ(q′)mi(q1)mi(q2)mj(q3)mj(−q1−q2−q3)⟩0−⟨mα(q)mβ(q′)⟩0⟨mi(q1)mi(q2)mj(q3)mj(−q1−q2−q3)⟩0]+O(u2).\begin{align*} \left\langle m_{\alpha}(\mathbf{q}) m_{\beta}\left(\mathbf{q}^{\prime}\right)\right\rangle= & \left\langle m_{\alpha}(\mathbf{q}) m_{\beta}\left(\mathbf{q}^{\prime}\right)\right\rangle_{0}-u \int \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q}_{1} \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q}_{\mathbf{d}^{d}} \mathbf{q}_{3}}{(2 \pi)^{3 d}} \\ & \times\left[\left\langle m_{\alpha}(\mathbf{q}) m_{\beta}\left(\mathbf{q}^{\prime}\right) m_{i}\left(\mathbf{q}_{1}\right) m_{i}\left(\mathbf{q}_{2}\right) m_{j}\left(\mathbf{q}_{3}\right) m_{j}\left(-\mathbf{q}_{1}-\mathbf{q}_{2}-\mathbf{q}_{3}\right)\right\rangle_{0}\right. \\ & \left.-\left\langle m_{\alpha}(\mathbf{q}) m_{\beta}\left(\mathbf{q}^{\prime}\right)\right\rangle_{0}\left\langle m_{i}\left(\mathbf{q}_{1}\right) m_{i}\left(\mathbf{q}_{2}\right) m_{j}\left(\mathbf{q}_{3}\right) m_{j}\left(-\mathbf{q}_{1}-\mathbf{q}_{2}-\mathbf{q}_{3}\right)\right\rangle_{0}\right] \\ & +\mathcal{O}\left(u^{2}\right) . \tag{5.12} \end{align*}⟨mα​(q)mβ​(q′)⟩=​⟨mα​(q)mβ​(q′)⟩0​−u∫(2π)3d ddq1​ ddqdd​q3​​×[⟨mα​(q)mβ​(q′)mi​(q1​)mi​(q2​)mj​(q3​)mj​(−q1​−q2​−q3​)⟩0​−⟨mα​(q)mβ​(q′)⟩0​⟨mi​(q1​)mi​(q2​)mj​(q3​)mj​(−q1​−q2​−q3​)⟩0​]+O(u2).​(5.12)​

To calculate ⟨OU⟩0\langle\mathcal{O U}\rangle_{0}⟨OU⟩0​ we need the unperturbed expectation value of the product of six mmm 's. This can be evaluated using Eq. (5.9) as the sum of all pair-wise contractions, 15 in all. Three contractions are obtained by first pairing mαm_{\alpha}mα​ to mβm_{\beta}mβ​, and then the remaining four mmm 's in U\mathcal{U}U. Clearly these contractions cancel exactly with corresponding ones in ⟨O⟩0⟨U⟩0\langle\mathcal{O}\rangle_{0}\langle\mathcal{U}\rangle_{0}⟨O⟩0​⟨U⟩0​. The only surviving terms involve contractions that connect O\mathcal{O}O to U\mathcal{U}U. This cancellation persists at all orders, and ⟨OUn⟩0c\left\langle\mathcal{O} \mathcal{U}^{n}\right\rangle_{0}^{c}⟨OUn⟩0c​ contains only terms in which all n+1n+1n+1 operators are connected by contractions. The remaining 12 pairings in ⟨OU⟩0\langle\mathcal{O U}\rangle_{0}⟨OU⟩0​ fall into two classes: (1) Four pairings involve contracting mαm_{\alpha}mα​ and mβm_{\beta}mβ​ to mmm 's with the same index, e.g.

⟨mα(q)mi(q1)⟩0⟨mβ(q′)mi(q2)⟩0⟨mj(q3)mj(−q1−q2−q3)⟩0=δαiδβiδjj(2π)3dδd(q+q1)δd(q′+q2)δd(q1+q2)(t+Kq2)(t+Kq′2)(t+Kq32)\begin{align*} \left\langle m_{\alpha}(\mathbf{q})\right. & \left.m_{i}\left(\mathbf{q}_{1}\right)\right\rangle_{0}\left\langle m_{\beta}\left(\mathbf{q}^{\prime}\right) m_{i}\left(\mathbf{q}_{2}\right)\right\rangle_{0}\left\langle m_{j}\left(\mathbf{q}_{3}\right) m_{j}\left(-\mathbf{q}_{1}-\mathbf{q}_{2}-\mathbf{q}_{3}\right)\right\rangle_{0} \\ = & \frac{\delta_{\alpha i} \delta_{\beta i} \delta_{j j}(2 \pi)^{3 d} \delta^{d}\left(\mathbf{q}+\mathbf{q}_{1}\right) \delta^{d}\left(\mathbf{q}^{\prime}+\mathbf{q}_{2}\right) \delta^{d}\left(\mathbf{q}_{1}+\mathbf{q}_{2}\right)}{\left(t+K q^{2}\right)\left(t+K q^{\prime 2}\right)\left(t+K q_{3}^{2}\right)} \tag{5.13} \end{align*}⟨mα​(q)=​mi​(q1​)⟩0​⟨mβ​(q′)mi​(q2​)⟩0​⟨mj​(q3​)mj​(−q1​−q2​−q3​)⟩0​(t+Kq2)(t+Kq′2)(t+Kq32​)δαi​δβi​δjj​(2π)3dδd(q+q1​)δd(q′+q2​)δd(q1​+q2​)​​(5.13)​

where we have used Eq. (5.6). After summing over iii and jjj, and integrating over q1,q2\mathbf{q}_{1}, \mathbf{q}_{2}q1​,q2​, and q3\mathbf{q}_{3}q3​, these terms make a contribution

−4unδαβ(2π)dδd(q+q′)(t+Kq2)2∫ ddq3(2π)d1t+Kq32\begin{equation*} -4 u \frac{n \delta_{\alpha \beta}(2 \pi)^{d} \delta^{d}\left(\mathbf{q}+\mathbf{q}^{\prime}\right)}{\left(t+K q^{2}\right)^{2}} \int \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q}_{3}}{(2 \pi)^{d}} \frac{1}{t+K q_{3}^{2}} \tag{5.14} \end{equation*}−4u(t+Kq2)2nδαβ​(2π)dδd(q+q′)​∫(2π)d ddq3​​t+Kq32​1​​(5.14)​

(2) Eight pairings involve contracting mαm_{\alpha}mα​ and mβm_{\beta}mβ​ to mmm 's with different indices, e.g.

⟨mα(q)mi(q1)⟩0⟨mβ(q′)mj(q3)⟩0⟨mi(q2)mj(−q1−q2−q3)⟩0=δαiδβjδij(2π)3dδd(q+q1)δd(q′+q3)δd(q1+q3)(t+Kq2)(t+Kq′2)(t+Kq22)\begin{gather*} \left\langle m_{\alpha}(\mathbf{q}) m_{i}\left(\mathbf{q}_{1}\right)\right\rangle_{0}\left\langle m_{\beta}\left(\mathbf{q}^{\prime}\right) m_{j}\left(\mathbf{q}_{3}\right)\right\rangle_{0}\left\langle m_{i}\left(\mathbf{q}_{2}\right) m_{j}\left(-\mathbf{q}_{1}-\mathbf{q}_{2}-\mathbf{q}_{3}\right)\right\rangle_{0} \\ =\frac{\delta_{\alpha i} \delta_{\beta j} \delta_{i j}(2 \pi)^{3 d} \delta^{d}\left(\mathbf{q}+\mathbf{q}_{1}\right) \delta^{d}\left(\mathbf{q}^{\prime}+\mathbf{q}_{3}\right) \delta^{d}\left(\mathbf{q}_{1}+\mathbf{q}_{3}\right)}{\left(t+K q^{2}\right)\left(t+K q^{\prime 2}\right)\left(t+K q_{2}^{2}\right)} \tag{5.15} \end{gather*}⟨mα​(q)mi​(q1​)⟩0​⟨mβ​(q′)mj​(q3​)⟩0​⟨mi​(q2​)mj​(−q1​−q2​−q3​)⟩0​=(t+Kq2)(t+Kq′2)(t+Kq22​)δαi​δβj​δij​(2π)3dδd(q+q1​)δd(q′+q3​)δd(q1​+q3​)​​(5.15)​

Summing over all indices, and integrating over the momenta leads to an overall contribution of

−8uδαβ(2π)dδd(q+q′)(t+Kq2)2∫ ddq2(2π)d1t+Kq22\begin{equation*} -8 u \frac{\delta_{\alpha \beta}(2 \pi)^{d} \delta^{d}\left(\mathbf{q}+\mathbf{q}^{\prime}\right)}{\left(t+K q^{2}\right)^{2}} \int \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q}_{2}}{(2 \pi)^{d}} \frac{1}{t+K q_{2}^{2}} \tag{5.16} \end{equation*}−8u(t+Kq2)2δαβ​(2π)dδd(q+q′)​∫(2π)d ddq2​​t+Kq22​1​​(5.16)​

Adding up both contributions, we obtain

⟨mα(q)mβ(q′)⟩=δαβ(2π)dδd(q+q′)t+Kq2[1−4u(n+2)t+Kq2∫ ddk(2π)d1t+Kk2+O(u2)].\begin{equation*} \left\langle m_{\alpha}(\mathbf{q}) m_{\beta}\left(\mathbf{q}^{\prime}\right)\right\rangle=\frac{\delta_{\alpha \beta}(2 \pi)^{d} \delta^{d}\left(\mathbf{q}+\mathbf{q}^{\prime}\right)}{t+K q^{2}}\left[1-\frac{4 u(n+2)}{t+K q^{2}} \int \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{k}}{(2 \pi)^{d}} \frac{1}{t+K k^{2}}+\mathcal{O}\left(u^{2}\right)\right] . \tag{5.17} \end{equation*}⟨mα​(q)mβ​(q′)⟩=t+Kq2δαβ​(2π)dδd(q+q′)​[1−t+Kq24u(n+2)​∫(2π)d ddk​t+Kk21​+O(u2)].​(5.17)​

5.3 Diagrammatic representation of perturbation theory

The calculations become more involved at higher orders in perturbation theory. A diagrammatic representation can be introduced to help keep track of all possible contractions. To calculate the ℓ\ellℓ-point expectation value ⟨∏i=1ℓmαi(qi)⟩\left\langle\prod_{i=1}^{\ell} m_{\alpha_{i}}\left(\mathbf{q}_{i}\right)\right\rangle⟨∏i=1ℓ​mαi​​(qi​)⟩, at ppp th order in uuu, proceed according to the following rules: (1) Draw ℓ\ellℓ external points labeled by (qi,αi)\left(\mathbf{q}_{i}, \alpha_{i}\right)(qi​,αi​) corresponding to the coordinates of the required correlation function. Draw ppp vertices with four legs each, labeled by internal momenta and indices, e.g. {(k1,i),(k2,i),(k3,j),(k4,j)}\left\{\left(\mathbf{k}_{1}, i\right),\left(\mathbf{k}_{2}, i\right),\left(\mathbf{k}_{3}, j\right),\left(\mathbf{k}_{4}, j\right)\right\}{(k1​,i),(k2​,i),(k3​,j),(k4​,j)}. Since the four legs are not equivalent, the four point vertex is indicated by two solid branches joined by a dotted line. (The extension to higher order interactions is straightforward.)

Fig. 5.1 Elements of the diagrammatic representation of perturbation theory. (2) Each point of the graph now corresponds to one factor of mαi(qi)m_{\alpha_{i}}\left(\mathbf{q}_{i}\right)mαi​​(qi​), and the unperturbed average of the product is computed by Wick's theorem. This is implemented by joining all external and internal points pair-wise, by lines connecting one point to another, in all topologically distinct ways; see (5) below. (3) The algebraic value of each such graph is obtained as follows: (i) A line joining a for a term u(2π)dδd(k1+k2+k3+k4)u(2 \pi)^{d} \delta^{d}\left(\mathbf{k}_{1}+\mathbf{k}_{2}+\mathbf{k}_{3}+\mathbf{k}_{4}\right)u(2π)dδd(k1​+k2​+k3​+k4​) (the delta-function insures that momentum is conserved).

1 Because of its original formulation in quantum field theory, the line joining two points is usually called a propagator. In this context, the line represents the world-line of a particle in time, while the perturbation U\mathcal{U}U is an "interaction" between particles. For the same reason, the Fourier index is called a "momentum". (4) Integrate over the 4p4 p4p internal momenta {ki}\left\{\mathbf{k}_{i}\right\}{ki​}, and sum over the 2p2 p2p internal indices. Note that each closed loop produces a factor of δii=n\delta_{i i}=nδii​=n at this stage. (5) There is a numerical factor of

(−1)pp!× number of different pairings leading to the same topology. \frac{(-1)^{p}}{p!} \times \text { number of different pairings leading to the same topology. }p!(−1)p​× number of different pairings leading to the same topology. 

The first contribution comes from the expansion of the exponential; the second merely states that graphs related by symmetry give the same result, and can be calculated once. (6) When calculating cumulants, only fully connected diagrams (without disjoint pieces) need to be included. This is a tremendous simplification.

For example, the diagrams appearing in the expansion for the propagator

⟨mα(q)mβ(q′)⟩≡⟺(q,α)(ql,β)\left\langle m_{\alpha}(q) m_{\beta}\left(q^{\prime}\right)\right\rangle \equiv \underset{(q, \alpha) \quad\left(q^{l}, \beta\right)}{\Longleftrightarrow}⟨mα​(q)mβ​(q′)⟩≡(q,α)(ql,β)⟺​

to second order are +++

5.4 Susceptibility

It is no accident that the correction term in Eq. (5.17) is similar in form to the unperturbed value. This is because the form of the two point correlation function is constrained by symmetries, as can be seen from the identity

⟨mα(q)mβ(q′)⟩=∫ddx∫ ddx′eiq⋅x+iq′⋅x′⟨mα(x)mβ(x′)⟩.\begin{equation*} \left\langle m_{\alpha}(\mathbf{q}) m_{\beta}\left(\mathbf{q}^{\prime}\right)\right\rangle=\int \mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{x} \int \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{x}^{\prime} \mathrm{e}^{i \boldsymbol{q} \cdot \mathbf{x}+i \mathbf{q}^{\prime} \cdot \mathbf{x}^{\prime}}\left\langle m_{\alpha}(\mathbf{x}) m_{\beta}\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)\right\rangle . \tag{5.18} \end{equation*}⟨mα​(q)mβ​(q′)⟩=∫ddx∫ ddx′eiq⋅x+iq′⋅x′⟨mα​(x)mβ​(x′)⟩.​(5.18)​

The two-point correlation function in real space must satisfy translation and rotation symmetry, and (in the high temperature phase) ⟨mα(x)mβ(x′)⟩=\left\langle m_{\alpha}(\mathbf{x}) m_{\beta}\left(\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right)\right\rangle=⟨mα​(x)mβ​(x′)⟩= δαβ⟨m1(x−x′)m1(0)⟩\delta_{\alpha \beta}\left\langle m_{1}\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right) m_{1}(\mathbf{0})\right\rangleδαβ​⟨m1​(x−x′)m1​(0)⟩. Transforming to center of mass and relative coordinates, the above integral becomes,

⟨mα(q)mβ(q′)⟩=∫dd(x+x′2)dd(x−x′)ei(q+q′)⋅(x+x′)/2ei(x−x′)⋅(q−q′)/2δαβ⟨m1(x−x′)m1(0)⟩≡(2π)dδd(q+q′)δαβS(q),\begin{align*} & \left\langle m_{\alpha}(\mathbf{q}) m_{\beta}\left(\mathbf{q}^{\prime}\right)\right\rangle \\ & =\int \mathrm{d}^{d}\left(\frac{\mathbf{x}+\mathbf{x}^{\prime}}{2}\right) \mathrm{d}^{d}\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right) \mathrm{e}^{i\left(\mathbf{q}+\mathbf{q}^{\prime}\right) \cdot\left(\mathbf{x}+\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right) / 2} \mathrm{e}^{i\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right) \cdot\left(\mathbf{q}-\mathbf{q}^{\prime}\right) / 2} \delta_{\alpha \beta}\left\langle m_{1}\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right) m_{1}(\mathbf{0})\right\rangle \\ & \equiv(2 \pi)^{d} \delta^{d}\left(\mathbf{q}+\mathbf{q}^{\prime}\right) \delta_{\alpha \beta} S(q), \tag{5.19} \end{align*}​⟨mα​(q)mβ​(q′)⟩=∫dd(2x+x′​)dd(x−x′)ei(q+q′)⋅(x+x′)/2ei(x−x′)⋅(q−q′)/2δαβ​⟨m1​(x−x′)m1​(0)⟩≡(2π)dδd(q+q′)δαβ​S(q),​(5.19)​

where

S(q)=⟨∣m1(q)∣2⟩=∫ddxeiq⋅x⟨m1(x−x′)m1(0)⟩\begin{equation*} \left.S(q)=\left.\langle | m_{1}(\mathbf{q})\right|^{2}\right\rangle=\int \mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{x e}^{i \boldsymbol{q} \cdot \mathbf{x}}\left\langle m_{1}\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\right) m_{1}(\mathbf{0})\right\rangle \tag{5.20} \end{equation*}S(q)=⟨∣m1​(q)∣2⟩=∫ddxeiq⋅x⟨m1​(x−x′)m1​(0)⟩​(5.20)​

is the quantity observed in scattering experiments (Section 2.4). From Eq. (5.17) we obtain

S(q)=1t+Kq2[1−4u(n+2)t+Kq2∫ ddk(2π)d1t+Kk2+O(u2)].\begin{equation*} S(q)=\frac{1}{t+K q^{2}}\left[1-\frac{4 u(n+2)}{t+K q^{2}} \int \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{k}}{(2 \pi)^{d}} \frac{1}{t+K k^{2}}+\mathcal{O}\left(u^{2}\right)\right] . \tag{5.21} \end{equation*}S(q)=t+Kq21​[1−t+Kq24u(n+2)​∫(2π)d ddk​t+Kk21​+O(u2)].​(5.21)​

It is useful to examine the expansion of the inverse quantity

S(q)−1=t+Kq2+4u(n+2)∫ddk(2π)d1t+Kk2+O(u2)\begin{equation*} S(q)^{-1}=t+K q^{2}+4 u(n+2) \int \frac{\mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{k}}{(2 \pi)^{d}} \frac{1}{t+K k^{2}}+\mathcal{O}\left(u^{2}\right) \tag{5.22} \end{equation*}S(q)−1=t+Kq2+4u(n+2)∫(2π)dddk​t+Kk21​+O(u2)​(5.22)​

In the high-temperature phase, Eq. (5.20) indicates that the q→0q \rightarrow 0q→0 limit of S(q)S(q)S(q) is just the magnetic susceptibility χ\chiχ. For this reason, S(q)S(q)S(q) is sometimes denoted by χ(q)\chi(q)χ(q). From Eq. (5.22), the inverse susceptibility is given by

χ−1(t)=t+4u(n+2)∫ddk(2π)d1t+Kk2+O(u2)\begin{equation*} \chi^{-1}(t)=t+4 u(n+2) \int \frac{\mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{k}}{(2 \pi)^{d}} \frac{1}{t+K k^{2}}+\mathcal{O}\left(u^{2}\right) \tag{5.23} \end{equation*}χ−1(t)=t+4u(n+2)∫(2π)dddk​t+Kk21​+O(u2)​(5.23)​

The susceptibility no longer diverges at t=0t=0t=0, since

χ−1(0)=4u(n+2)∫ddk(2π)d1Kk2=4(n+2)uKSd(2π)d∫0Λdkkd−3=4(n+2)uKKd(Λd−2d−2)\begin{align*} \chi^{-1}(0) & =4 u(n+2) \int \frac{\mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{k}}{(2 \pi)^{d}} \frac{1}{K k^{2}}=\frac{4(n+2) u}{K} \frac{S_{d}}{(2 \pi)^{d}} \int_{0}^{\Lambda} d k k^{d-3} \\ & =\frac{4(n+2) u}{K} K_{d}\left(\frac{\Lambda^{d-2}}{d-2}\right) \tag{5.24} \end{align*}χ−1(0)​=4u(n+2)∫(2π)dddk​Kk21​=K4(n+2)u​(2π)dSd​​∫0Λ​dkkd−3=K4(n+2)u​Kd​(d−2Λd−2​)​(5.24)​

is a finite number (Kd≡Sd/(2π)d)\left(K_{d} \equiv S_{d} /(2 \pi)^{d}\right)(Kd​≡Sd​/(2π)d). This is because in the presence of uuu the critical temperature is reduced to a negative value. The modified critical point is obtained by requiring χ−1(tc)=0\chi^{-1}\left(t_{c}\right)=0χ−1(tc​)=0, and hence from Eq. (5.23), to order of uuu,

tc=−4u(n+2)∫ddk(2π)d1tc+Kk2≈−4u(n+2)KdΛd−2(d−2)K<0.\begin{equation*} t_{c}=-4 u(n+2) \int \frac{\mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{k}}{(2 \pi)^{d}} \frac{1}{t_{c}+K k^{2}} \approx-\frac{4 u(n+2) K_{d} \Lambda^{d-2}}{(d-2) K}<0 . \tag{5.25} \end{equation*}tc​=−4u(n+2)∫(2π)dddk​tc​+Kk21​≈−(d−2)K4u(n+2)Kd​Λd−2​<0.​(5.25)​

Fig. 5.2 The divergence of susceptibility occurs at a lower temperature due to the interaction uuu.

How does the perturbed susceptibility diverge at the shifted critical point? From Eq. (5.23),

χ−1(t)−χ−1(tc)=t−tc+4u(n+2)∫ddk(2π)d(1t+Kk2−1tc+Kk2)=(t−tc)[1−4u(n+2)K2∫ ddk(2π)d1k2(k2+(t−tc)/K)+O(u2)].\begin{align*} \chi^{-1}(t)-\chi^{-1}\left(t_{c}\right) & =t-t_{c}+4 u(n+2) \int \frac{\mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{k}}{(2 \pi)^{d}}\left(\frac{1}{t+K k^{2}}-\frac{1}{t_{c}+K k^{2}}\right) \\ & =\left(t-t_{c}\right)\left[1-\frac{4 u(n+2)}{K^{2}} \int \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{k}}{(2 \pi)^{d}} \frac{1}{k^{2}\left(k^{2}+\left(t-t_{c}\right) / K\right)}+\mathcal{O}\left(u^{2}\right)\right] . \tag{5.26} \end{align*}χ−1(t)−χ−1(tc​)​=t−tc​+4u(n+2)∫(2π)dddk​(t+Kk21​−tc​+Kk21​)=(t−tc​)[1−K24u(n+2)​∫(2π)d ddk​k2(k2+(t−tc​)/K)1​+O(u2)].​(5.26)​

In going from the first equation to the second, we have changed the position of tct_{c}tc​ from one denominator to another. Since tc=O(u)t_{c}=\mathcal{O}(u)tc​=O(u), the corrections due to this change only appear at O(u2)\mathcal{O}\left(u^{2}\right)O(u2). The final integral has dimensions of [kd−4]\left[k^{d-4}\right][kd−4]. For d>4d>4d>4 it is dominated by the largest momenta and scales as Λd−4\Lambda^{d-4}Λd−4. For 2<d<42<d<42<d<4, the integral is convergent at both limits. Its magnitude is therefore set by the momentum scale ξ−1=(t−tc)/K\xi^{-1}=\sqrt{\left(t-t_{c}\right) / K}ξ−1=(t−tc​)/K​, which can be used to make the integrand dimensionless. Hence, in these dimensions,

χ−1(t)=(t−tc)[1−4u(n+2)K2c(Kt−tc)2−d/2+O(u2)]\begin{equation*} \chi^{-1}(t)=\left(t-t_{c}\right)\left[1-\frac{4 u(n+2)}{K^{2}} c\left(\frac{K}{t-t_{c}}\right)^{2-d / 2}+\mathcal{O}\left(u^{2}\right)\right] \tag{5.27} \end{equation*}χ−1(t)=(t−tc​)[1−K24u(n+2)​c(t−tc​K​)2−d/2+O(u2)]​(5.27)​

where ccc is a constant. For d<4d<4d<4, the correction term at the order of uuu diverges at the phase transition, masking the unperturbed singularity of χ\chiχ with γ=1\gamma=1γ=1. Thus the perturbation series is inherently inapplicable for describing the divergence of susceptibility in d<4d<4d<4. The same conclusion arises in calculating any other quantity perturbatively. Although we start by treating uuu as the perturbation parameter, it is important to realize that it is not dimensionless; u/K2u / K^{2}u/K2 has dimensions of (length) d−4{ }^{d-4}d−4. The perturbation series for any quantity then takes the form X(t,u)=X0(t)[1+f(ua4−d/K2,uξ4−d/K2)]X(t, u)=X_{0}(t)\left[1+f\left(u a^{4-d} / K^{2}, u \xi^{4-d} / K^{2}\right)\right]X(t,u)=X0​(t)[1+f(ua4−d/K2,uξ4−d/K2)], where fff is a power series. The two length scales aaa and ξ\xiξ are available to construct dimensionless variables. Since ξ\xiξ diverges close to the critical point, there is an inherent failure of the perturbation series. The effective (dimensionless) perturbation parameter diverges at tct_{c}tc​ and is not small, making it an inherently ineffective expansion parameter.

5.5 Perturbative RG (first order)

The last section demonstrates how various expectation values associated with the Landau-Ginzburg Hamiltonian can be calculated perturbatively in powers of uuu. However, the perturbative series is inherently divergent close to the critical point and cannot be used to characterize critical behavior in dimensions d≤4d \leq 4d≤4. K.G. Wilson showed that it is possible to combine perturbative and renormalization group approaches into a systematic method for calculating critical exponents. Accordingly, we shall extend the RG calculation of Gaussian model in Section 3.7 to the Landau-Ginzburg Hamiltonian, by treating U=u∫ ddxm4\mathcal{U}=u \int \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{x} m^{4}U=u∫ ddxm4 as a perturbation. (1) Coarse grain: This is the most difficult step of the RG procedure. As before, subdivide the fluctuations into two components as,

In the partition function,

Z=∫Dm~~(q)Dσ⃗(q)exp⁡{−∫0Λddq(2π)d(t+Kq22)(∣m~(q)∣2+∣σ(q)∣2)−m~(q),σ⃗(q)]}\begin{align*} Z= & \int \mathcal{D} \widetilde{\widetilde{m}}(\mathbf{q}) \mathcal{D} \vec{\sigma}(\mathbf{q}) \exp \left\{-\int_{0}^{\Lambda} \frac{\mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{d}}\left(\frac{t+K q^{2}}{2}\right)\right. \tag{5.29}\\ & \left.\left.\left(|\widetilde{m}(\mathbf{q})|^{2}+|\sigma(\mathbf{q})|^{2}\right)-\mathcal{\tilde { m }}(\mathbf{q}), \vec{\sigma}(\mathbf{q})\right]\right\} \end{align*}Z=​∫Dm(q)Dσ(q)exp{−∫0Λ​(2π)dddq​(2t+Kq2​)(∣m(q)∣2+∣σ(q)∣2)−m~(q),σ(q)]}​(5.29)​

the two sets of modes are mixed by the operator U\mathcal{U}U. Formally, the result of integrating out {σ⃗(q)}\{\vec{\sigma}(\mathbf{q})\}{σ(q)} can be written as

Z=∫Dm~~(q)exp⁡{−∫0Λ/b ddq(2π)d(t+Kq22)∣m~(q)∣2}×exp⁡{−nV2∫Λ/bΛddq(2π)dln⁡(t+Kq2)}⟨e−U[m~~,σ~]⟩σ≡∫Dm~~(q)e−βH~[m~~].\begin{align*} Z= & \int \mathcal{D} \widetilde{\widetilde{m}}(\mathbf{q}) \exp \left\{-\int_{0}^{\Lambda / b} \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{d}}\left(\frac{t+K q^{2}}{2}\right)|\widetilde{m}(\mathbf{q})|^{2}\right\} \\ & \times \exp \left\{-\frac{n V}{2} \int_{\Lambda / b}^{\Lambda} \frac{\mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{d}} \ln \left(t+K q^{2}\right)\right\}\left\langle\mathrm{e}^{-\mathcal{U}[\widetilde{\widetilde{m}}, \widetilde{\sigma}]}\right\rangle_{\sigma} \tag{5.30}\\ \equiv & \int \mathcal{D} \widetilde{\widetilde{m}}(\mathbf{q}) \mathrm{e}^{-\beta \widetilde{\mathcal{H}}[\widetilde{\widetilde{m}}]} . \end{align*}Z=≡​∫Dm(q)exp{−∫0Λ/b​(2π)d ddq​(2t+Kq2​)∣m(q)∣2}×exp{−2nV​∫Λ/bΛ​(2π)dddq​ln(t+Kq2)}⟨e−U[m,σ]⟩σ​∫Dm(q)e−βH[m].​(5.30)​

Here we have defined the partial averages

⟨O⟩σ≡∫Dσ⃗(q)ZσOexp⁡[−∫Λ/bΛddq(2π)d(t+Kq22)∣σ(q)∣2],\begin{equation*} \langle\mathcal{O}\rangle_{\sigma} \equiv \int \frac{\mathcal{D} \vec{\sigma}(\mathbf{q})}{Z_{\sigma}} \mathcal{O} \exp \left[-\int_{\Lambda / b}^{\Lambda} \frac{\mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{d}}\left(\frac{t+K q^{2}}{2}\right)|\sigma(\mathbf{q})|^{2}\right], \tag{5.31} \end{equation*}⟨O⟩σ​≡∫Zσ​Dσ(q)​Oexp[−∫Λ/bΛ​(2π)dddq​(2t+Kq2​)∣σ(q)∣2],​(5.31)​

with Zσ=∫Dσ⃗(q)exp⁡{−βH0[σ⃗]}Z_{\sigma}=\int \mathcal{D} \vec{\sigma}(\mathbf{q}) \exp \left\{-\beta \mathcal{H}_{0}[\vec{\sigma}]\right\}Zσ​=∫Dσ(q)exp{−βH0​[σ]}, being the Gaussian partition function associated with the short wavelength fluctuations. From Eq. (5.30), we obtain

βH~[m⃗~]=Vδfb0+∫0Λ/b ddq(2π)d(t+Kq22)∣m~(q)∣2−ln⁡⟨e−U[m~~,σˉ]⟩σ.\begin{equation*} \widetilde{\beta \mathcal{H}}[\widetilde{\vec{m}}]=V \delta f_{b}^{0}+\int_{0}^{\Lambda / b} \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{d}}\left(\frac{t+K q^{2}}{2}\right)|\widetilde{m}(\mathbf{q})|^{2}-\ln \left\langle\mathrm{e}^{-\mathcal{U}[\widetilde{\widetilde{m}}, \bar{\sigma}]}\right\rangle_{\sigma} . \tag{5.32} \end{equation*}βH​[m]=Vδfb0​+∫0Λ/b​(2π)d ddq​(2t+Kq2​)∣m(q)∣2−ln⟨e−U[m,σˉ]⟩σ​.​(5.32)​

The final expression can be calculated perturbatively as,

ln⁡⟨e−U⟩σ=−⟨U⟩σ+12(⟨U2⟩σ−⟨U⟩σ2)+⋯+(−1)ℓℓ!×ℓ th cumulant of U+⋯\begin{align*} \ln \left\langle\mathrm{e}^{-\mathcal{U}}\right\rangle_{\sigma}= & -\langle\mathcal{U}\rangle_{\sigma}+\frac{1}{2}\left(\left\langle\mathcal{U}^{2}\right\rangle_{\sigma}-\langle\mathcal{U}\rangle_{\sigma}^{2}\right)+\cdots \\ & +\frac{(-1)^{\ell}}{\ell!} \times \ell \text { th cumulant of } \mathcal{U}+\cdots \tag{5.33} \end{align*}ln⟨e−U⟩σ​=​−⟨U⟩σ​+21​(⟨U2⟩σ​−⟨U⟩σ2​)+⋯+ℓ!(−1)ℓ​×ℓ th cumulant of U+⋯​(5.33)​

The cumulants can be computed using the rules set in the previous sections. For example, at the first order we need to compute

While the recursion relation for uuu at this order is identical to that obtained by dimensional analysis, the one for ttt is different. {t+δℓdt dℓ=(1+2δℓ)(t+4u(n+2)Sd(2π)d1t+KΛ2Λdδℓ)u+δℓdu dℓ=(1+(4−d)δℓ)u(5.43)\left\{\begin{array}{l} t+\delta \ell \frac{\mathrm{d} t}{\mathrm{~d} \ell}=(1+2 \delta \ell)\left(t+4 u(n+2) \frac{S_{d}}{(2 \pi)^{d}} \frac{1}{t+K \Lambda^{2}} \Lambda^{d} \delta \ell\right) \tag{5.43}\\ u+\delta \ell \frac{\mathrm{d} u}{\mathrm{~d} \ell}=(1+(4-d) \delta \ell) u \end{array}\right.{t+δℓ dℓdt​=(1+2δℓ)(t+4u(n+2)(2π)dSd​​t+KΛ21​Λdδℓ)u+δℓ dℓdu​=(1+(4−d)δℓ)u​(5.43)

The recursion relation for uuu is easily integrated to give u(ℓ)=u0e(4−d)ℓ=u0b(4−d)u(\ell)=u_{0} \mathrm{e}^{(4-d) \ell}=u_{0} b^{(4-d)}u(ℓ)=u0​e(4−d)ℓ=u0​b(4−d). The recursion relations can be linearized in the vicinity of the fixed point t∗=u∗=0t^{*}=u^{*}=0t∗=u∗=0, by setting t=t∗+δtt=t^{*}+\delta tt=t∗+δt and u=u∗+δuu=u^{*}+\delta uu=u∗+δu, as

d dℓ(δtδu)=(24(n+2)KdΛd−2K04−d)(δtδu)(5.45)\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{~d} \ell}\binom{\delta t}{\delta u}=\left(\begin{array}{cc} 2 & \frac{4(n+2) K_{d} \Lambda^{d-2}}{K} \tag{5.45}\\ 0 & 4-d \end{array}\right)\binom{\delta t}{\delta u} dℓd​(δuδt​)=(20​K4(n+2)Kd​Λd−2​4−d​)(δuδt​)(5.45)

In the differential form of the recursion relations, the eigenvalues of the matrix determine the relevance of operators. Since the above matrix has zero elements on one side, its eigenvalues are the diagonal elements, and as in the Gaussian model we can identify yt=2y_{t}=2yt​=2, and yu=4−dy_{u}=4-dyu​=4−d. The results at this order are identical to those obtained from dimensional analysis on the Gaussian model. The only difference is in the eigendirections. The exponent yt=2y_{t}=2yt​=2 is still associated with u=0u=0u=0, while yu=4−dy_{u}=4-dyu​=4−d is actually associated with the direction t=−4u(n+2)KdΛd−2/Kt=-4 u(n+2) K_{d} \Lambda^{d-2} / Kt=−4u(n+2)Kd​Λd−2/K. This agrees with the shift in the transition temperature calculated to order of uuu from the susceptibility.

Fig. 5.3 RG flows obtained perturbatively to first order.

For d>4d>4d>4 the Gaussian fixed point has only one unstable direction associated with yty_{t}yt​. It thus correctly describes the phase transition. For d<4d<4d<4 it has two relevant directions and is unstable. Unfortunately, the recursion relations have no other fixed point at this order and it appears that we have learned little from the perturbative RG. However, since we are dealing with an alternating series we can anticipate that the recursion relations at the next order are modified to

{dt dℓ=2t+4u(n+2)KdΛdt+KΛ2−Au2 du dℓ=(4−d)u−Bu2,(5.46)\left\{\begin{array}{l} \frac{\mathrm{d} t}{\mathrm{~d} \ell}=2 t+\frac{4 u(n+2) K_{d} \Lambda^{d}}{t+K \Lambda^{2}}-A u^{2} \tag{5.46}\\ \frac{\mathrm{~d} u}{\mathrm{~d} \ell}=(4-d) u-B u^{2}, \end{array}\right.{ dℓdt​=2t+t+KΛ24u(n+2)Kd​Λd​−Au2 dℓ du​=(4−d)u−Bu2,​(5.46)

with AAA and BBB positive. There is now an additional fixed point at u∗=(4−d)/Bu^{*}=(4-d) / Bu∗=(4−d)/B for d<4d<4d<4. For a systematic perturbation theory we need to keep the parameter uuu small. Thus the new fixed point can be explored systematically only for small ϵ=4−d\epsilon=4-dϵ=4−d; we are led to consider an expansion in the dimension of space in the vicinity of d=4d=4d=4 ! For a calculation valid at O(ϵ)\mathcal{O}(\boldsymbol{\epsilon})O(ϵ) we have to keep track of terms of second order in the recursion relation for uuu, but only to first order in that of ttt. It is thus unnecessary to calculate the term AAA in the above recursion relation.

5.6 Perturbative RG (second order)

The coarse-grained Hamiltonian at second order in U\mathcal{U}U is

βH~[m~~]=Vδfb0+∫0Λ/b ddq(2π)d(t+Kq22)∣m~(q)∣2+⟨U⟩σ−12(⟨U2⟩σ−⟨U⟩σ2)+O(U3).\begin{align*} \widetilde{\beta \mathcal{H}}[\widetilde{\widetilde{m}}]= & V \delta f_{b}^{0}+\int_{0}^{\Lambda / b} \frac{\mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{q}}{(2 \pi)^{d}}\left(\frac{t+K q^{2}}{2}\right) \\ & |\widetilde{m}(\mathbf{q})|^{2}+\langle\mathcal{U}\rangle_{\sigma}-\frac{1}{2}\left(\left\langle\mathcal{U}^{2}\right\rangle_{\sigma}-\langle\mathcal{U}\rangle_{\sigma}^{2}\right)+O\left(\mathcal{U}^{3}\right) . \tag{5.47} \end{align*}βH​[m]=​Vδfb0​+∫0Λ/b​(2π)d ddq​(2t+Kq2​)∣m(q)∣2+⟨U⟩σ​−21​(⟨U2⟩σ​−⟨U⟩σ2​)+O(U3).​(5.47)​

To calculate (⟨U2⟩σ−⟨U⟩σ2)\left(\left\langle\mathcal{U}^{2}\right\rangle_{\sigma}-\langle\mathcal{U}\rangle_{\sigma}^{2}\right)(⟨U2⟩σ​−⟨U⟩σ2​) we need to consider all possible decompositions of two U\mathcal{U}U s into m⃗~\widetilde{\vec{m}}m and σ⃗\vec{\sigma}σ as in Eq. (5.34). Since each U\mathcal{U}U can be broken up into six types of terms as in Eq. (5.35), there are 36 such possibilities for two U\mathcal{U}U s which can be arranged in a 6×66 \times 66×6 matrix, as below. Many of the elements of this matrix are either zero, or can be neglected at this stage, due to a number of considerations: (1) All the 11 terms involving at least one factor of type [1] are zero because they cannot be contracted into a connected piece, and the disconnected elements cancel in calculating the cumulant. (2) An additional 12 terms (such as [2] ×[3]\times[3]×[3] ) involve an odd number of σ⃗\vec{\sigma}σ s and are zero due to their parity. (3) Two terms, [2] ×[5]\times[5]×[5] and [5]×[2][5] \times[2][5]×[2], involve a vertex where two σ⃗\vec{\sigma}σ s are contracted together, leaving a m⃗~(q<)\widetilde{\vec{m}}\left(\mathbf{q}^{<}\right)m(q<)and a σ⃗(q>)\vec{\sigma}\left(\mathbf{q}^{>}\right)σ(q>). This configuration is not allowed by the δ\deltaδ-function which ensures momentum conservation for the vertex, as by construction q>+q<≠0\mathbf{q}^{>}+\mathbf{q}^{<} \neq \mathbf{0}q>+q<=0. (4) Terms [3] ×[6],[4]×[6]\times[6],[4] \times[6]×[6],[4]×[6], and their partners by exchange have two factors of m⃗~\widetilde{\vec{m}}m. They involve two-loop integrations, and appear as corrections to the coefficient t~\widetilde{t}t. We shall denote their net effect by AAA, which as noted earlier does not need to be known precisely at this order. (5) The term [5] ×[5]\times[5]×[5] also involves two factors of m⃗~\widetilde{\vec{m}}m, while [2] ×[2]\times[2]×[2] includes six such factors. The latter is important as it indicates that the space of parameters is not closed at this order. Even if initially zero, a term proportional to m6m^{6}m6 is generated under RG. In fact, considerations of momentum conservation indicate that both these terms are zero for q=0\mathbf{q}=0q=0, and are thus contributions to q2m2q^{2} m^{2}q2m2 and q2m6q^{2} m^{6}q2m6, respectively. We shall comment on their effect later on. (6) The contributions resulting from [6] × [6] are constants, and will be collectively denoted by u2Vδfb2u^{2} V \delta f_{b}^{2}u2Vδfb2​.

5.7 The ϵ\epsilonϵ-expansion

The parameter space ( K,t,uK, t, uK,t,u ) is no longer closed at this order; several new interactions proportional to m2,m4m^{2}, m^{4}m2,m4, and m6m^{6}m6, all consistent with symmetries of the problem, appear in the coarse-grained Hamiltonian at second order in uuu. Linearizing the recursion relations in the vicinity of the fixed point results in

At the Gaussian fixed point, t∗=u∗=0t^{*}=u^{*}=0t∗=u∗=0, and Eq. (5.45) is reproduced. At the new fixed point of Eqs. (5.55),

d dℓ(δtδu)=(2−4(n+2)K4Λ4K2Λ4K2ϵ4(n+8)K4……O(ϵ2)ϵ−8(n+8)K4Λ4K2Λ4K2ϵ4(n+8)K4)(δtδu)(5.57)\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{~d} \ell}\binom{\delta t}{\delta u}=\left(\begin{array}{ccc} 2-\frac{4(n+2) K_{4} \Lambda^{4}}{K^{2} \Lambda^{4}} \frac{K^{2} \epsilon}{4(n+8) K_{4}} & \ldots \ldots \tag{5.57}\\ \mathcal{O}\left(\epsilon^{2}\right) & \epsilon-\frac{8(n+8) K_{4} \Lambda^{4}}{K^{2} \Lambda^{4}} & \frac{K^{2} \epsilon}{4(n+8) K_{4}} \end{array}\right)\binom{\delta t}{\delta u} dℓd​(δuδt​)=(2−K2Λ44(n+2)K4​Λ4​4(n+8)K4​K2ϵ​O(ϵ2)​……ϵ−K2Λ48(n+8)K4​Λ4​​4(n+8)K4​K2ϵ​​)(δuδt​)(5.57)

We have not explicitly calculated the top element of the second column as it is not necessary for calculating the eigenvalues. This is because the lower element of the first column is zero to order of ϵ\epsilonϵ. Hence the eigenvalues are determined by the diagonal elements alone. The first eigenvalue is positive, controlling the instability of the fixed point,

yt=2−(n+2)(n+8)ϵ+O(ϵ2)\begin{equation*} y_{t}=2-\frac{(n+2)}{(n+8)} \epsilon+\mathcal{O}\left(\epsilon^{2}\right) \tag{5.58} \end{equation*}yt​=2−(n+8)(n+2)​ϵ+O(ϵ2)​(5.58)​

The second eigenvalue,

yu=−ϵ+O(ϵ2),\begin{equation*} y_{u}=-\epsilon+\mathcal{O}\left(\epsilon^{2}\right), \tag{5.59} \end{equation*}yu​=−ϵ+O(ϵ2),​(5.59)​

is negative for d<4d<4d<4. The new fixed point thus has co-dimension of one and can describe the phase transition in these dimensions. It is quite satisfying that while various intermediate results, such as the position of the fixed point, depend on such microscopic parameters as KKK and Λ\LambdaΛ, the final eigenvalues are pure numbers, only depending on nnn and d=4−ϵd=4-\epsilond=4−ϵ. These eigenvalues characterize the universality classes of rotational symmetry breaking in d<4d<4d<4, with short-range interactions. (As discussed in the problem section, long-range interaction may lead to new universality classes.)

The divergence of the correlation length, ξ∼(δt)−ν\xi \sim(\delta t)^{-\nu}ξ∼(δt)−ν, is controlled by the exponent

ν=1yt={2[1−(n+2)2(n+8)ϵ]}−1=12+14n+2n+8ϵ+O(ϵ2)\begin{equation*} \nu=\frac{1}{y_{t}}=\left\{2\left[1-\frac{(n+2)}{2(n+8)} \epsilon\right]\right\}^{-1}=\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{4} \frac{n+2}{n+8} \epsilon+\mathcal{O}\left(\epsilon^{2}\right) \tag{5.60} \end{equation*}ν=yt​1​={2[1−2(n+8)(n+2)​ϵ]}−1=21​+41​n+8n+2​ϵ+O(ϵ2)​(5.60)​

The singular part of the free energy scales as f∼(δt)2−αf \sim(\delta t)^{2-\alpha}f∼(δt)2−α, and the heat capacity diverges with the exponent

α=2−dν=2−(4−ϵ)2[1+12n+2n+8ϵ]=4−n2(n+8)ϵ+O(ϵ2)\begin{equation*} \alpha=2-d \nu=2-\frac{(4-\epsilon)}{2}\left[1+\frac{1}{2} \frac{n+2}{n+8} \epsilon\right]=\frac{4-n}{2(n+8)} \epsilon+\mathcal{O}\left(\epsilon^{2}\right) \tag{5.61} \end{equation*}α=2−dν=2−2(4−ϵ)​[1+21​n+8n+2​ϵ]=2(n+8)4−n​ϵ+O(ϵ2)​(5.61)​

To complete the calculation of critical exponents, we need the eigenvalue associated with the (relevant) symmetry breaking field hhh. This is easily found by adding a term −h⃗⋅∫ ddxm⃗(x)=−h⃗⋅m⃗(q=0)-\vec{h} \cdot \int \mathrm{~d}^{d} \mathbf{x} \vec{m}(\mathbf{x})=-\vec{h} \cdot \vec{m}(\mathbf{q}=\mathbf{0})−h⋅∫ ddxm(x)=−h⋅m(q=0) to the Hamiltonian. This term is not affected by coarse graining or rescaling, and after the renormalization step changes to −zh⃗⋅m⃗′(q′=0)-z \vec{h} \cdot \vec{m}^{\prime}\left(\mathbf{q}^{\prime}=\mathbf{0}\right)−zh⋅m′(q′=0), implying

h′=zh=b1+d2h,⟹yh=1+d2+O(ϵ2)=3−ϵ2+O(ϵ2).\begin{equation*} h^{\prime}=z h=b^{1+\frac{d}{2}} h, \quad \Longrightarrow \quad y_{h}=1+\frac{d}{2}+\mathcal{O}\left(\epsilon^{2}\right)=3-\frac{\epsilon}{2}+\mathcal{O}\left(\epsilon^{2}\right) . \tag{5.62} \end{equation*}h′=zh=b1+2d​h,⟹yh​=1+2d​+O(ϵ2)=3−2ϵ​+O(ϵ2).​(5.62)​

The vanishing of magnetization as T→Tc−T \rightarrow T_{c}^{-}T→Tc−​is controlled by the exponent

β=d−yhyt=(4−ϵ2−1)×12(1+n+22(n+8)ϵ+O(ϵ2))=12−32(n+8)ϵ+O(ϵ2)\begin{align*} \beta & =\frac{d-y_{h}}{y_{t}}=\left(\frac{4-\epsilon}{2}-1\right) \times \frac{1}{2}\left(1+\frac{n+2}{2(n+8)} \epsilon+\mathcal{O}\left(\epsilon^{2}\right)\right) \tag{5.63}\\ & =\frac{1}{2}-\frac{3}{2(n+8)} \epsilon+\mathcal{O}\left(\epsilon^{2}\right) \end{align*}β​=yt​d−yh​​=(24−ϵ​−1)×21​(1+2(n+8)n+2​ϵ+O(ϵ2))=21​−2(n+8)3​ϵ+O(ϵ2)​(5.63)​

while the susceptibility diverges as χ∼(δt)−γ\chi \sim(\delta t)^{-\gamma}χ∼(δt)−γ, with

γ=2yh−dyt=2×12(1+n+22(n+8)ϵ)=1+n+22(n+8)ϵ+O(ϵ2).\begin{equation*} \gamma=\frac{2 y_{h}-d}{y_{t}}=2 \times \frac{1}{2}\left(1+\frac{n+2}{2(n+8)} \epsilon\right)=1+\frac{n+2}{2(n+8)} \epsilon+O\left(\epsilon^{2}\right) . \tag{5.64} \end{equation*}γ=yt​2yh​−d​=2×21​(1+2(n+8)n+2​ϵ)=1+2(n+8)n+2​ϵ+O(ϵ2).​(5.64)​

Using the above results, we can estimate various exponents as a function of ddd and nnn. For example, for n=1n=1n=1, by setting ϵ=1\epsilon=1ϵ=1 or 2 in Eqs. (5.60) and Eqs. (5.63) we obtain the values ν(1)≈0.58,ν(2)≈0.67\nu(1) \approx 0.58, \nu(2) \approx 0.67ν(1)≈0.58,ν(2)≈0.67, and β(1)≈0.33\beta(1) \approx 0.33β(1)≈0.33, β(2)≈0.17\beta(2) \approx 0.17β(2)≈0.17. The best estimates of these exponents in d=3d=3d=3 are ν≈0.63\nu \approx 0.63ν≈0.63, and β≈0.32\beta \approx 0.32β≈0.32. In d=2d=2d=2 the exact values are known to be ν=1\nu=1ν=1 and β=0.125\beta=0.125β=0.125. The estimates for β\betaβ are quite good, while those for ν\nuν are less reliable. It is important to note that in all cases these estimates are an improvement over the mean field (saddle point) values. Since the expansion is around four dimensions, the results are more reliable in d=3d=3d=3 than in d=2d=2d=2. In any case, they correctly describe the decrease of β\betaβ with lowering dimension, and the increase of ν\nuν. They also correctly describe the trends with varying nnn at a fixed ddd as indicated by the following table of exponents α(n)\alpha(n)α(n).

Although the sign of α\alphaα is incorrectly predicted at this order for n=2n=2n=2 and 3 , the decrease of α\alphaα with increasing nnn is correctly described.

5.8 Irrelevance of other interactions

The fixed point Hamiltonian at O(ϵ)\mathcal{O}(\epsilon)O(ϵ) (from Eqs. 5.55) has only three terms

βH∗=K2∫Λddx[(∇m)2−(n+2)(n+8)ϵΛ2m2+ϵΛ−ϵ2(n+8)KK4m4],\begin{equation*} \beta \mathcal{H}^{*}=\frac{K}{2} \int_{\Lambda} \mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{x}\left[(\nabla m)^{2}-\frac{(n+2)}{(n+8)} \epsilon \Lambda^{2} m^{2}+\frac{\epsilon \Lambda^{-\epsilon}}{2(n+8)} \frac{K}{K_{4}} m^{4}\right], \tag{5.65} \end{equation*}βH∗=2K​∫Λ​ddx[(∇m)2−(n+8)(n+2)​ϵΛ2m2+2(n+8)ϵΛ−ϵ​K4​K​m4],​(5.65)​

and explicitly depends on the imposed cutoff Λ∼1/a\Lambda \sim 1 / aΛ∼1/a (unlike the exponents). However, as described in Section 3.4, the starting point for RG must be the most general Hamiltonian consistent with symmetries. We also discovered that even if some of these terms are left out of the original Hamiltonian, they are generated under coarse graining. At second order in uuu, terms proportional to m6m^{6}m6 were generated; higher powers of mmm will appear at higher orders in uuu.

Let us focus on a rotationally symmetric Hamiltonian for h⃗=0\vec{h}=0h=0. We can incorporate all terms consistent with this symmetry in a perturbative RG by setting βH=βH0+U\beta \mathcal{H}=\beta \mathcal{H}_{0}+\mathcal{U}βH=βH0​+U, where

βH0=∫ddx[t2m2+K2(∇m)2+L2(∇2m)2+⋯ ]\begin{equation*} \beta \mathcal{H}_{0}=\int \mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{x}\left[\frac{t}{2} m^{2}+\frac{K}{2}(\nabla m)^{2}+\frac{L}{2}\left(\nabla^{2} m\right)^{2}+\cdots\right] \tag{5.66} \end{equation*}βH0​=∫ddx[2t​m2+2K​(∇m)2+2L​(∇2m)2+⋯]​(5.66)​

includes all quadratic (Gaussian terms), while the remaining higher order terms are placed in the perturbation

U=∫ddx[um4+vm2(∇m)2+⋯+u6m6+⋯+u8m8+⋯ ].\begin{equation*} \mathcal{U}=\int \mathrm{d}^{d} \mathbf{x}\left[u m^{4}+v m^{2}(\nabla m)^{2}+\cdots+u_{6} m^{6}+\cdots+u_{8} m^{8}+\cdots\right] . \tag{5.67} \end{equation*}U=∫ddx[um4+vm2(∇m)2+⋯+u6​m6+⋯+u8​m8+⋯].​(5.67)​

After coarse graining, and steps (ii) and (iii) of RG in real space, x=bx′\mathbf{x}=b \mathbf{x}^{\prime}x=bx′ and m⃗~=ζm⃗′\widetilde{\vec{m}}=\zeta \vec{m}^{\prime}m=ζm′, the renormalized weight depends on the parameters

{t↦bdζ2t~=b2t~K↦bd−2ζ2K~=KL↦bd−4ζ2L~=b−2L~⋮u↦bdζ4u~=b4−du~v↦bd−2ζ4v~=b2−dv~⋮u6↦bdζ6u~6=b6−2du~6u8↦bdζ8u~8=b8−3du~8⋮(5.68)\begin{cases}t \mapsto & b^{d} \zeta^{2} \widetilde{t}=b^{2} \widetilde{t} \tag{5.68}\\ K \mapsto & b^{d-2} \zeta^{2} \widetilde{K}=K \\ L \mapsto & b^{d-4} \zeta^{2} \widetilde{L}=b^{-2} \widetilde{L} \\ & \vdots \\ u \mapsto & b^{d} \zeta^{4} \widetilde{u}=b^{4-d} \widetilde{u} \\ v \mapsto & b^{d-2} \zeta^{4} \widetilde{v}=b^{2-d} \widetilde{v} \\ & \vdots \\ u_{6} \mapsto & b^{d} \zeta^{6} \widetilde{u}_{6}=b^{6-2 d} \widetilde{u}_{6} \\ u_{8} \mapsto & b^{d} \zeta^{8} \widetilde{u}_{8}=b^{8-3 d} \widetilde{u}_{8} \\ & \vdots\end{cases}⎩⎨⎧​t↦K↦L↦u↦v↦u6​↦u8​↦​bdζ2t=b2tbd−2ζ2K=Kbd−4ζ2L=b−2L⋮bdζ4u=b4−dubd−2ζ4v=b2−dv⋮bdζ6u6​=b6−2du6​bdζ8u8​=b8−3du8​⋮​(5.68)

The second set of equalities are obtained by choosing ζ2=b2−dK/K~=b2−d[1+\zeta^{2}=b^{2-d} K / \widetilde{K}=b^{2-d}[1+ζ2=b2−dK/K=b2−d[1+ O(u2,uv,v2,⋯ )]\left.\mathcal{O}\left(u^{2}, u v, v^{2}, \cdots\right)\right]O(u2,uv,v2,⋯)], such that K′=KK^{\prime}=KK′=K. By choosing an infinitesimal rescaling, the recursion relations take the differential forms

{dt dℓ=2t+O(u,v,u6,u8,⋯ )dK dℓ=0 dL dℓ=−2L+O(u2,uv,v2,⋯ )⋮du dℓ=ϵu−Bu2+O(uv,v2,⋯ )dv dℓ=(−2+ϵ)v+O(u2,uv,v2,⋯ )⋮du6 dℓ=(−2+2ϵ)u6+O(u3,u62,⋯ )du8 dℓ=(−4+3ϵ)u8+O(u3,u2u6,⋯ )⋮\left\{\begin{align*} & \frac{\mathrm{d} t}{\mathrm{~d} \ell}= 2 t+\mathcal{O}\left(u, v, u_{6}, u_{8}, \cdots\right) \tag{5.69}\\ & \frac{\mathrm{d} K}{\mathrm{~d} \ell}= 0 \\ & \frac{\mathrm{~d} L}{\mathrm{~d} \ell}=-2 L+\mathcal{O}\left(u^{2}, u v, v^{2}, \cdots\right) \\ & \vdots \\ & \frac{\mathrm{d} u}{\mathrm{~d} \ell}= \epsilon u-B u^{2}+\mathcal{O}\left(u v, v^{2}, \cdots\right) \\ & \frac{\mathrm{d} v}{\mathrm{~d} \ell}=(-2+\epsilon) v+\mathcal{O}\left(u^{2}, u v, v^{2}, \cdots\right) \\ & \vdots \\ & \frac{\mathrm{d} u_{6}}{\mathrm{~d} \ell}=(-2+2 \epsilon) u_{6}+\mathcal{O}\left(u^{3}, u_{6}^{2}, \cdots\right) \\ & \frac{\mathrm{d} u_{8}}{\mathrm{~d} \ell}=(-4+3 \epsilon) u_{8}+\mathcal{O}\left(u^{3}, u^{2} u_{6}, \cdots\right) \\ & \vdots \end{align*}\right.⎩⎨⎧​​ dℓdt​=2t+O(u,v,u6​,u8​,⋯) dℓdK​=0 dℓ dL​=−2L+O(u2,uv,v2,⋯)⋮ dℓdu​=ϵu−Bu2+O(uv,v2,⋯) dℓdv​=(−2+ϵ)v+O(u2,uv,v2,⋯)⋮ dℓdu6​​=(−2+2ϵ)u6​+O(u3,u62​,⋯) dℓdu8​​=(−4+3ϵ)u8​+O(u3,u2u6​,⋯)⋮​(5.69)​

These recursion relations describe two fixed points: (1) The Gaussian fixed point, t∗=L∗=u∗=v∗=⋯=0t^{*}=L^{*}=u^{*}=v^{*}=\cdots=0t∗=L∗=u∗=v∗=⋯=0, and K≠0K \neq 0K=0, has eigenvalues

yt0=2,yL0=−2,⋯ ,yu0=+ϵ,yv0=−2+ϵ,⋯ ,y60=−2+2ϵ,y80=−4+3ϵ,⋯ .\begin{align*} & y_{t}^{0}=2, y_{L}^{0}=-2, \cdots, y_{u}^{0}=+\epsilon, y_{v}^{0}=-2+\epsilon, \cdots, \\ & y_{6}^{0}=-2+2 \epsilon, y_{8}^{0}=-4+3 \epsilon, \cdots . \tag{5.70} \end{align*}​yt0​=2,yL0​=−2,⋯,yu0​=+ϵ,yv0​=−2+ϵ,⋯,y60​=−2+2ϵ,y80​=−4+3ϵ,⋯.​(5.70)​

(2) Setting Eqs. (5.69) to zero, a non-trivial fixed point is located at

t∗∼u∗∼O(ϵ),L∗∼v∗∼⋯∼O(ϵ2),u6∗∼⋯∼O(ϵ3),⋯\begin{equation*} t^{*} \sim u^{*} \sim \mathcal{O}(\epsilon), \quad L^{*} \sim v^{*} \sim \cdots \sim \mathcal{O}\left(\epsilon^{2}\right), \quad u_{6}^{*} \sim \cdots \sim \mathcal{O}\left(\epsilon^{3}\right), \cdots \tag{5.71} \end{equation*}t∗∼u∗∼O(ϵ),L∗∼v∗∼⋯∼O(ϵ2),u6∗​∼⋯∼O(ϵ3),⋯​(5.71)​

The stability of this fixed point is determined by the matrix,

d dℓ(δtδL⋮δuδv⋮)=(2−O(u∗)O(ϵ)⋯O(1)O(1)⋯O(ϵ2)−2+O(ϵ)⋮⋱O(ϵ2)O(ϵ)O(ϵ2)O(ϵ)⋮)(δtδL⋮δuδv⋮).(5.72)\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{~d} \ell}\left(\begin{array}{c} \delta t \tag{5.72}\\ \delta L \\ \vdots \\ \delta u \\ \delta v \\ \vdots \end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{cccccc} 2-\mathcal{O}\left(u^{*}\right) & \mathcal{O}(\epsilon) & \cdots & \mathcal{O}(1) & \mathcal{O}(1) & \cdots \\ \mathcal{O}\left(\epsilon^{2}\right) & -2+\mathcal{O}(\epsilon) & & & & \\ \vdots & & \ddots & & & \\ \mathcal{O}\left(\epsilon^{2}\right) & \mathcal{O}(\epsilon) & & & & \\ \mathcal{O}\left(\epsilon^{2}\right) & \mathcal{O}(\epsilon) & & & & \\ \vdots & & & & & \end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c} \delta t \\ \delta L \\ \vdots \\ \delta u \\ \delta v \\ \vdots \end{array}\right) . dℓd​​δtδL⋮δuδv⋮​​=​2−O(u∗)O(ϵ2)⋮O(ϵ2)O(ϵ2)⋮​O(ϵ)−2+O(ϵ)O(ϵ)O(ϵ)​⋯⋱​O(1)​O(1)​⋯​​​δtδL⋮δuδv⋮​​.(5.72)

Note that as ϵ→0\epsilon \rightarrow 0ϵ→0, the non-trivial fixed part, its eigenvalues and eigendirections continuously go over to the Gaussian fixed points. Hence the eigenvalues can only be corrected by order of ϵ\epsilonϵ, and Eq. (5.70) is modified to

yt=2−n+2n+8ϵ+O(ϵ2),yL=−2+O(ϵ),⋯yu=−ϵ+O(ϵ2),yv=−2+O(ϵ),⋯ ,y6=−2+O(ϵ),y8=−4+O(ϵ),⋯\begin{gather*} y_{t}=2-\frac{n+2}{n+8} \epsilon+\mathcal{O}\left(\epsilon^{2}\right), \quad y_{L}=-2+\mathcal{O}(\epsilon), \cdots \\ y_{u}=-\epsilon+\mathcal{O}\left(\epsilon^{2}\right), y_{v}=-2+\mathcal{O}(\epsilon), \cdots, y_{6}=-2+\mathcal{O}(\epsilon), y_{8}=-4+\mathcal{O}(\epsilon), \cdots \tag{5.73} \end{gather*}yt​=2−n+8n+2​ϵ+O(ϵ2),yL​=−2+O(ϵ),⋯yu​=−ϵ+O(ϵ2),yv​=−2+O(ϵ),⋯,y6​=−2+O(ϵ),y8​=−4+O(ϵ),⋯​(5.73)​

While the eigenvalues are still labeled with the coefficients of the various terms in the Landau-Ginzburg expansion, we must remember that the actual eigendirections are now rotated away from the axes of this parameter space, although their largest projection is still parallel to the corresponding axis.

Whereas the Gaussian fixed point has two relevant directions in d<4d<4d<4, the generalized O(n)O(n)O(n) fixed point has only one relevant direction corresponding to yty_{t}yt​. At least perturbatively, this fixed point has a basin of attraction of codimension one, and thus describes the phase transition. The original concept of Kadanoff scaling is thus explicitly realized and the universality of exponents is traced to the irrelevance (at least perturbatively) of the multitude of other possible interactions. The perturbative approach does not exclude the existence of other fixed points at finite values of these parameters. The uniqueness of the critical exponents observed so far for each universality class, and their proximity to the values calculated from the ϵ\epsilonϵ-expansion, suggests that postulating such non-perturbative fixed points is unnecessary.

5.9 Comments on the ϵ\epsilonϵ-expansion

The perturbative implementation of RG for the Landau-Ginzburg Hamiltonian was achieved by K.G. Wilson in the early 1970s; the ϵ\epsilonϵ-expansion was developed jointly with M.E. Fisher. This led to a flurry of activity in the topic which still continues. Wilson was awarded the Nobel Prize in 1982. Historical details can be found in his Nobel lecture reprinted in Rev. Mod. Phys. 55, 583 (1983). A few comments on the ϵ\epsilonϵ-expansion are in order at this stage. (1) Higher orders, and convergence of the series: Calculating the exponents to O(ϵ)2\mathcal{O}(\epsilon)^{2}O(ϵ)2 and beyond, by going to order of U3\mathcal{U}^{3}U3 and higher, is quite complicated as we have to keep track of many more interactions. It is in fact quite unappealing that the intermediate steps of the RG explicitly keep track of the cutoff scale Λ\LambdaΛ, while the final exponents must be independent of it. In fact there are a number of field theoretical RG schemes (dimensional regularization, summing leading divergences, etc.) that avoid many of these difficulties. These methods are harder to visualize and will not be described here. All higher order calculations are currently performed using one of these schemes. It is sometimes (but not always) possible to prove that these approaches are consistent with each other, and can be carried out to all orders. In principle, the problem of evaluating critical exponents in d=3d=3d=3 is now solved: simple computations lead to approximate results, while more refined calculations should provide better answers. The situation is somewhat like finding the energy levels of a He atom, which cannot be done exactly, but which may be obtained with sufficient accuracy using various approximation methods.

To estimate how reliable the exponents are, we need some information on the convergence of the series. The ϵ\epsilonϵ expansion has been carried out to the fifth order, and the results for the exponent γ\gammaγ, for n=1n=1n=1 at d=3d=3d=3, are

γ=1+0.167ϵ+0.077ϵ2−0.049ϵ3+0.180ϵ4−0.415ϵ51.2385±0.0025=1.000,1.167,1.244,1.195,1.375,0.96\begin{align*} \gamma & =1+0.167 \epsilon+0.077 \epsilon^{2}-0.049 \epsilon^{3}+0.180 \epsilon^{4}-0.415 \epsilon^{5} \\ 1.2385 \pm 0.0025 & =1.000,1.167,1.244,1.195,1.375,0.96 \tag{5.74} \end{align*}γ1.2385±0.0025​=1+0.167ϵ+0.077ϵ2−0.049ϵ3+0.180ϵ4−0.415ϵ5=1.000,1.167,1.244,1.195,1.375,0.96​(5.74)​

The second line compares the values obtained at different orders by substituting ϵ=1\epsilon=1ϵ=1, with the best estimate of γ≈1.2385\gamma \approx 1.2385γ≈1.2385 in d=3d=3d=3. Note that the elements of the series have alternating signs. The truncated series evaluated at ϵ=1\epsilon=1ϵ=1 improves up to third order, beyond which it starts to oscillate, and deviates from the left hand side. These are characteristics of an asymptotic series. It can be proved that for large ppp, the coefficients in the expansion of most quantities scale as ∣fp∣∼cp!a−p\left|f_{p}\right| \sim c p!a^{-p}∣fp​∣∼cp!a−p. As a result, the ϵ\epsilonϵ-expansion series is non-convergent, but can be evaluated by the Borel summation method, using the identity ∫0∞dxxpe−x=p\int_{0}^{\infty} \mathrm{d} x x^{p} \mathrm{e}^{-x}=p∫0∞​dxxpe−x=p !, as

f(ϵ)=∑pfpϵp=∑pfpϵp1p!∫0∞dxxpe−x=∫0∞dxe−x∑pfp(ϵx)pp!.\begin{equation*} f(\epsilon)=\sum_{p} f_{p} \epsilon^{p}=\sum_{p} f_{p} \epsilon^{p} \frac{1}{p!} \int_{0}^{\infty} \mathrm{d} x x^{p} \mathrm{e}^{-x}=\int_{0}^{\infty} \mathrm{d} x \mathrm{e}^{-x} \sum_{p} \frac{f_{p}(\epsilon x)^{p}}{p!} . \tag{5.75} \end{equation*}f(ϵ)=p∑​fp​ϵp=p∑​fp​ϵpp!1​∫0∞​dxxpe−x=∫0∞​dxe−xp∑​p!fp​(ϵx)p​.​(5.75)​

The final summation (which is convergent) results in a function of xxx which can be integrated to give f(ϵ)f(\epsilon)f(ϵ). Very good estimates of exponents in d=3d=3d=3, such as the one for γ\gammaγ quoted above, are obtained by this summation method. There is no indication of any singularity in the exponents up to ϵ=2\epsilon=2ϵ=2, corresponding to the lower critical dimension d=2d=2d=2. (2) The 1/n\mathbf{1 / n}1/n expansion: The fixed point position,

u∗=(t∗+KΛ2)2(4−d)4(n+8)KdΛdu^{*}=\frac{\left(t^{*}+K \Lambda^{2}\right)^{2}(4-d)}{4(n+8) K_{d} \Lambda^{d}}u∗=4(n+8)Kd​Λd(t∗+KΛ2)2(4−d)​

vanishes as n→∞n \rightarrow \inftyn→∞. This suggests that a controlled 1/n1 / n1/n expansion of the critical exponents is also possible. Indeed such an expansion can be developed by a number of methods, such as a saddle point expansion that takes advantage of the exponential dependence of the Hamiltonian on nnn, or by an exact resummation of the perturbation series. Equation (5.58) in this limit gives,

yt=lim⁡n→∞[2−n+2n−8(4−d)]=d−2⟹ν=1d−2.\begin{equation*} y_{t}=\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left[2-\frac{n+2}{n-8}(4-d)\right]=d-2 \quad \Longrightarrow \quad \nu=\frac{1}{d-2} . \tag{5.76} \end{equation*}yt​=n→∞lim​[2−n−8n+2​(4−d)]=d−2⟹ν=d−21​.​(5.76)​

This result is exact in dimensions 4<d<24<d<24<d<2. Above four dimensions the mean field value of 1/21 / 21/2 is recovered, while for d<2d<2d<2 there is no order.

  1. Longitudinal susceptibility: While there is no reason for the longitudinal susceptibility to diverge at the mean-field level, it in fact does so due to fluctuations in dimensions d<4d<4d<4.
